courses.name: Introduction to Quebec Literature and Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to various aspects of Qubec literature and culture through the study of literary texts, cinema, and artistic productions, and their role in the evolution of a distinct Qubec society. The course also familiarizes students with important socio-cultural and political events, which participated in the evolution of Qubec society and provide a better understanding of Qubec literature.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Quebec Literature and Culture
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The Department reserves the right to place students in the language course appropriate to their level of linguistic competence, based on the results of a placement test. For more information on taking the placement test and guidelines on how to enroll into our courses, please visit: www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/enrolment_guidelines .

cmCourseInfo.description: A theoretical and practical consideration of the ways we learn a second language, with a historical overview and critical evaluation of the various methodologies that have been developed; the role of cultural studies in language learning; practical evalujation and development of syllabus, course and text materials.
cmCourseInfo.title: Second Language Learning (formerly JFI225Y1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL 221Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by theh French Placement Test.

notes.name: Course Note

cmCourseInfo.description: A practical introduction to concepts, methods and problems of literary analysis, based on a detailed study of selected French and Francophone literary texts from various genres and periods. Students master the basic techniques of literary analysis and use them in short essays.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Literary Analysis
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The Department reserves the right to place students in the language course appropriate to their level of linguistic competence, based on the results of a placement test. For more information on taking the placement test and guidelines on how to enroll into our courses, please visit: www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/enrolment_guidelines

courses.name: Introduction to Research and Writing in Literary Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Survey and practical applications of literary research tools, printed and digitalized, with training sessions at the library. Topics covered include rules and conventions of scholarly writing, organizing a paper, choice of appropriate style, developing arguments, proper usage of footnotes and bibliographical references, and material presentation of papers and dissertations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Research and Writing in Literary Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

The Department reserves the right to place students in the language course appropriate to their level of linguistic competence, based on the results of a placement test. For more information on taking the placement test and guidelines on how to enroll into our courses, please visit: www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/enrolment_guidelines .

courses.name: The Structure of Modern French: An Introduction

cmCourseInfo.description: A general introductory course on the structure of the French language including a descriptive study of meaning, sound, word, and sentence structure.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Structure of Modern French: An Introduction
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The Department reserves the right to place students in the language course appropriate to their level of linguistic competence, based on the results of a placement test. For more information on taking the placement test and guidelines on how to enroll into our courses, please visit: www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/enrolment_guidelines .

courses.name: Introduction to the History of the French Language

cmCourseInfo.description: A discovery of a long and fascinating history, stretching from the spoken Latin of the Gauls to the many varieties of French found today all over the world via the investigation of the social, political and cultural causes of language change. Our focus includes topics such as medieval bilingualism, the regulation of language through the Acadmie franaise, the political use of the French language, the emergence of the Francophonie and modern Canadian French.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to the History of the French Language
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL 221Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The Department reserves the right to place students in the language course appropriate to their level of linguistic competence, based on the results of a placement test. For more information on taking the placement test and guidelines on how to enroll into our courses, please visit: www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/enrolment_guidelines .

courses.name: Introduction to the Linguistic Analysis of French

cmCourseInfo.description: An analytical study of contemporary French phonetics and phonology, morphology, syntax and semantics. This course is designed to prepare students for more advanced study of French linguistics at the 300 and 400 levels.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to the Linguistic Analysis of French

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

For more information on taking the placement test and guidelines on how to enroll into our courses, please visit: www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/enrolment_guidelines

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Course does not count towards any program in French.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For more information on how to enrol, please visit: http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/focus/research#ROP

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: New Course Added: June 26, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: An analysis of selected prose texts of the last hundred years written by major French women authors, emphasizing themes and textual strategies used to represent the female subject, her relationship to language, and the role of ethnicity, class, and gender in the construction of identity.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary French Women's Prose Fiction

courses.name: Relations between Text and Other Media

cmCourseInfo.description: Literary texts and other forms of media (photographs, cinematographic images, paintings) have been associated in a fascinating relation in hundreds of works of French literature. An exploration of this inextricable weaving together of verbal and visual experiences as it pertains to literature through the study of interdisciplinary theoretical texts focused on photography, painting, and cinema.
cmCourseInfo.title: Relations between Text and Other Media

cmCourseInfo.description: Literature of the 20th and 21st centuries speaks of contesting social and literary figures of authority, of challenging traditional literary structures and of accentuating creativity and subjectivity. An exploration of the thematic and formal structures that challenge traditional forms of thinking and writing in contemporary literature from Qubec and other French-speaking parts of Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Quebec and French-Canadian Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: Religious fervour, chivalry, romance and ribald humour, heroic deeds, marvellous adventures, and exotic travels as found in selected texts from the French Middle Ages. Readings in modern French translations with appropriate reference to the original language.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medieval French Literature

courses.name: Laughter and Thought in French Renaissance Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of the fascinating literary diversity, prose, theatre and poetry essential to the changing humanistic discourse of the French Renaissance and Baroque periods. The underscoring of important historical events - Reformation, Great Discoveries, Printing - to explain the philosophical and literary values produced by such violent times.
cmCourseInfo.title: Laughter and Thought in French Renaissance Literature

courses.name: French Literature in the Time of Revolutions and Industrialization

cmCourseInfo.description: The long 19th century (1789-1914) is characterized by change: from political upheavals to literary, scientific, and media revolutions, the spread of literacy, and the rapid development of industrialization and colonization. A study of the evolution of literature (genres, forms, movements), as influenced by these changing socio-political and economic contexts.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Literature in the Time of Revolutions and Industrialization

cmCourseInfo.description: The fundamentals of postcolonial theories, with emphasis on how they relate to the Francophone world. The dialogue between fiction and theory, as well as the modalities of a coherent Francophone postcolonial identity in a global world.
cmCourseInfo.title: Postcolonialism: Francophone Literatures

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to literary theory through the study of particular theories underlying specific approaches to the literary text. Concepts and problems central to literary theory, and the writings of major critics and theoreticians.
cmCourseInfo.title: Literary Theory

cmCourseInfo.description: Survey of the main literary genres and analysis of their features, with in-depth study of two of the genres: narrative (epic poem, novel, short narrative), lyric poetry, drama (tragedy, comedy, farce, mystery play), essay. Readings of selected texts, chosen for their representative potential and their historical relevance.
cmCourseInfo.title: Literary Genres

courses.name: Special Topics in Linguistics or Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will be part of an international agreement between the University of Toronto and the University of Nice. Students will be taking the course in Nice.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Linguistics or Literature

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Only students participating in the Third Year Abroad in Nice are eligible for these courses. For more information, contact the Study Elsewhere Advisor at french.elsewhere@utoronto.ca or 416 926 1300, ext. 3141.

courses.name: Special Topics in Linguistics or Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will be part of an international agreement between the University of Toronto and the University of Nice. Students will be taking the course in Nice.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Linguistics or Literature

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Only students participating in the Third Year Abroad in Nice are eligible for these courses. For more information, contact the Study Elsewhere Advisor at french.elsewhere@utoronto.ca or 416 926 1300, ext. 3141.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room changed: October 4, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of the phonological system of modern French based on actual samples of speech taken from different regional varieties and socio-economic groups.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Phonology and Phonetics

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of the distribution and relationships of the syntagmatic components of contemporary French; of sentential structure, including the principles of coordination, subordination and expansion; and of major theoretical approaches.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Syntax

cmCourseInfo.description: The relationship between language use and social factors such as socio-economic status, social context and gender of speaker. Theoretical notions are derived through the analysis of specific data, focusing on Canadian French and other varieties spoken in the Americas.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sociolinguistics of French

courses.name: Experimental and Quantitative Methods for the Study of French

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the foundations of quantitative analysis and experimental research on French. Topics include differences between quantitative and qualitative analyses; hypothesis formulation; experimental design; and data collection and analysis including basic statistical methods. Phenomena investigated come from Canadian and European varieties as well as studies of second language learners.
cmCourseInfo.title: Experimental and Quantitative Methods for the Study of French

courses.name: Teaching French as a Second Language

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides an introduction to the communicative approach in recent methods and pedagogical materials published in France and in North America. Emphasis is put on the various interpretations of the communicative approach in teaching FSL, with reference to theoretical issues and historical background.
cmCourseInfo.title: Teaching French as a Second Language

cmCourseInfo.description: Various approaches to the notion of meaning; its functioning at all levels of representation.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Semantics

courses.name: Bilingualism and second language acquisition of French

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of the cognitive aspects of bilingualism and language acquisition among early and late bilingual French speakers. Topics will include psycholinguistic processing and representation in the multilingual mind; the role and analysis of input in second language acquisition; patterns of interlanguage grammatical development; the nature and sources of intra and interlearner variation; and the effect of instruction on learning.
cmCourseInfo.title: Bilingualism and second language acquisition of French

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced interdisciplinary research seminar devoted to specific issues of Qubcois literature and culture. Focus on a literary genre, a particular subject matter, a literary movement, or based on a multidisciplinary approach to cinema, arts, and music.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Quebec Literature:

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced seminar dedicated to specific issues of the Francophone literature and culture. Focusing on an author, a literary genre, or based on a multidisciplinary approach involving cinema, arts and music, each seminar reflects the professors current research. For more information, see http://www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/courses/french_literature
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Francophone Literatures

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced, research-oriented seminar devoted to specific issues of French literature and culture. Focus on a literary genre, a particular subject or literary movement, or based on a multidisciplinary approach involving cinema, arts, and music. For more information, see http://www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/courses/french_literature
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in French Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced, research-oriented seminar devoted to questions concerning the authors practice, originality, and oeuvre. Production, performance and prominence, characteristic genres, religious and philosophical thought, theoretical reflection on literature, language, and belonging as aspects of the analysis of one single authors body of writing. For more information, see http://www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/courses/french_literature
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Time changed: July 10, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: This course aims to assure an understanding of Old French, to read most of the medieval texts. From a selection of texts, it explores the form of the language in various centuries and regions and provide a basis for understanding the history of French language. This course is also listed in the offerings of the Graduate department of French.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medieval French Language

courses.name: Teaching French in Context: Language, Culture, and Society

cmCourseInfo.description: The course investigates the relation between language, society and culture and study in depth various aspects of French and Francophone civilization, with particular focus on the development and integration of materials for use in the classroom by using contemporary texts and audio-visual documents.
cmCourseInfo.title: Teaching French in Context: Language, Culture, and Society

cmCourseInfo.description: Analysis of bibliographical tools available for the selection of literary materials for the FSL classroom. Study of representative works of interest to young people such as novels, detective stories, cartoons, with special emphasis on socio-cultural aspects. Critical analysis of various pedagogical approaches useful for the Experiential Learning component: students participate in a school internship.
cmCourseInfo.title: Teaching Young People's Literature

courses.name: Special Topics in Advanced Linguistics I

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced seminar on a specific aspect of French linguistics. For more information, see http://www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/courses/french_linguistics
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Advanced Linguistics I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Varies according to particular course offering; consult the French Studies Undergraduate brochure (www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate) for exact prerequisites.

notes.name: Course Note

cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Advanced Linguistics II

cmCourseInfo.description: A research project on a literary, linguistic, or second language learning topic to be proposed by the student and supervised by a Faculty member, culminating in a major research paper. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Senior Essay
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any 300+ FRE Linguistics/Literature/Second Language Learning course. Permission of Department.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Applicants must complete the Ballot for Admission and the Description of Project Form, available at http://www.french.utoronto.ca/courses/145 and return them, duly signed by their supervisor, to Linda Lamisong, room 226, Odette Hall. An electronic version of the application must be forwarded to french.undergraduate@utoronto.ca. The deadlines are as follows: August 28, 2017 for F and Y courses; November 27, 2017 for S courses; March 29, 2018 for the 2018 summer session.

cmCourseInfo.description: A research project on a literary, linguistic, or second language learning topic to be proposed by the student and supervised by a Faculty member on a topic of common interest, including readings, discussions, papers. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Study
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any 300+ FRE Linguistics/Literature/Second Language Learning course. Permission of Department.
